1.subquestion: What does Vieta's formulas say about roots of polynomials if they have rational coefficients (and hence integers)?

subanswer.text: According to Vieta's Formulas, if a cubic or quartic equation ($ax^3+bx^2+cx+d=0$) has three real roots ($\alpha,\beta,$ and $\gamma$), where at least one pair consists of irrational conjugates such as $(\pm \sqrt {m})(\pm \sqrt {n})$, then those pairs must multiply together to give either m or n; since their product isn't zero but rather some positive nonzero quantity like 'k', any other possible third solution would also need to satisfy its own multiplication property relative to k -- resulting again only in integral values! Thus our final conclusion here states clearly enough: Any quadratics whose solutions include complexities beyond simple fractions/integers MUST HAVE COMPLEX SOLUTIONS AS WELL TO MAINTAIN INTEGRALITY OF ALL TERMS AND PARTICULARLY THEIR ROOTS OR YIELDS... This implies how important factorization plays during algebra computations involving higher degrees than just linear equations – especially within domains governed through rules dictating unique conditions imposed upon factors themselves prior being divided amongst variables forming part greater than unity degree functions . That means every term present inside square brackets should equal something divisible across multiple terms outside them too!! Therefore knowing everything gets back down onto basic algebraic principles helps simplify calculations further making sure errors don’t creep up while doing manipulations required nowadays.. Which makes sense considering modern computer programming techniques rely heavily around math expressions written using symbols instead words due increased computing power needed compared earlier times ago.... And so without going deep dive specific details behind exact workings let go ahead discuss potential paths forward taking current understanding already established above!... 2.subquestion: Using the fact that opposite additive inverse sums to zero, calculate the sum of $4 - \sqrt{11}$, $-\sqrt{11}$, and $\sqrt{11}$.

subanswer.text: Adding the given opposites yields $(4 - \sqrt{11})+(-\sqrt{11})+(\sqrt{11})=(4+\cancel{-}\sqrt{11}+\cancel{\sqrt{11}})=4$. The answer is 4.

2.subquestion: A general form of a quadratic polynomial with leading coefficient 1 and having roots $a+\sqrt{b}$ and $a-\sqrt{b}$ is ...

subanswer.text: Such a polynomial will look like $$q(x)=(x-(a+\sqrt b))(x-(a-\sqrt b))$$ Expanding yields $$\begin{aligned} q(x)&=(x-a)^2-(\sqrt{b})^2\\&=(x^2-2ax+(a^2-b))\end{aligned}$$ Hence, after simplifying we arrive at the desired expression namely:- $$x^{2}-2ax+(a^2-b)$$

1.subquestion: What does Vieta's formulas say about roots of polynomials if they have rational coefficients (and hence integers)?

subanswer.text: Vieta's formulas state certain properties concerning sums and products of roots taken one pair at a time for any polynomial equation. Specifically relating our problem here, let us suppose our quadratic polynomial p(x) takes the form ax^2 + bx + c whose leading coefficient 'a', middle term ‘b’, and constant term ’c’are required. Given it is stated above that sqrt(11) lies within such polynomial implies -sqrt(11) also exists because square roots exist in both directions along real line . Thus making another possible root x=-sqrt(11). Hence according to Vieta's formulas product (-sqrt(11)+4)/ac=product of each conjugate pair i.e., √11*(-√11) giving negative eleven since multiplication operation overhere involves subtraction while adding them backgives zeroes meaning irrational terms cancel out leaving behind purely rational denominator when divided against itself thus providing quotient value equal to unity! Consequently , fractional division becomes unnecessary so numerator equates exactly correspondingly whereas nonintegral part disappears rendering just whole number outcome ! Answer comes forth immediately without additional calculations needed : [eval(1/1)=1]. Moreover
